pa-tagline: Integrated Telegram account management system: website admin panel, automated bot, access control and analytics in one product.
pa-problem-text: Managing multiple Telegram accounts for giveaways manually is inefficient and prone to errors. Users need anonymity, while administrators need centralized control and transparency without accessing sensitive user data directly.
pa-solution-text: I built a comprehensive system consisting of a Telegram bot for automated actions, a web-based admin dashboard for management, and a secure database. The system ensures safe participation in giveaways while providing real-time analytics.
pa-feat-1: Role System: Granular access control for admins and users.
pa-feat-2: Access Control: Secure login and action authorization.
pa-feat-3: Logging: Detailed logs of all bot and admin actions.
pa-feat-4: Automation Logic: Smart scripts for joining giveaways.
pa-feat-5: Monitoring: Real-time status of all connected accounts.
pa-concept-text: The main goal of the system is to automate account participation in giveaways, ensure user anonymity, and provide the administrator with full control through a web interface. The architecture is modular and scalable: new features can be added without rewriting the entire codebase.
pa-admin-li1: Create users with ID, name and username.
pa-admin-li2: Assign roles, restrictions and access levels.
pa-admin-li3: Link one or multiple accounts to a user.
pa-user-li1: Bot access is granted only after activation via the website.
pa-user-li2: Manage multiple accounts under one ID.
pa-user-li3: View statistics: participation, success rate, activity.
pa-user-li4: Secure workflow with codes and passwords.
pa-bot-li1: Automatically participates in giveaways: subscriptions, captchas, scripted actions.
pa-bot-li2: Tracks account activity and displays statistics to the user.
pa-bot-li3: Synchronized with the website via database: panel changes instantly affect the bot.
pa-bot-li4: Asynchronous processing allows managing multiple accounts simultaneously.
pa-bot-li5: Only active and authorized accounts participate in campaigns.
pa-db-struct-p: Users, accounts, statistics and logs. State is preserved after restart, analytics and export available.
pa-db-manage-p: Add, edit and delete users/accounts, control bot actions and permissions.
pa-db-ui-p: Tables, cards, filtering, activity visualization, hover effects and responsive navigation.
pa-sec-li1: Personal data is hidden and accessible only to the administrator.
pa-sec-li2: Account access is protected by codes and passwords.
pa-sec-li3: Bot and administrator actions are logged without exposing private information.
pa-sec-li4: Modular architecture reduces risks of errors and vulnerabilities.
pa-adv-li1: Centralized management of users and accounts.
pa-adv-li2: Automation of giveaway participation without routine manual tasks.
pa-adv-li3: Detailed analytics for accounts and users.
pa-adv-li5: Easy scalability and integration of new modules.
pa-gal-cap1: Admin dashboard: access, roles, action control.
pa-gal-cap2: User journey: Telegram interaction and participation scenarios.
pa-gal-cap3: Infrastructure: stability, data storage and scalability.
pa-res-text: This is not just a bot, but a full-fledged system: every action is under control, every account is protected, and the administrator sees the complete picture in real time. The solution is suitable for scalable automation, modular development and transparent Telegram account management.

python.tech-page-title: Python: A Fundamental Breakdown of the Ecosystem
python.tech-main-desc: Python is a high-level language that combines incredible readability with powerful low-level capabilities. Its architecture is built around the CPython virtual machine, which executes compiled bytecode, making it an ideal tool for automation and backend development.
python.tech-card-1-text: Analysis of the virtual machine operation, bytecode interpretation, and stack-based architecture.
python.tech-card-2-text: In-depth memory management through reference counting and a heuristic garbage collector.
python.tech-card-3-text: A cooperative multitasking model based on asyncio for high-load systems.
python.full-sec-1-text: When you run a script, Python first translates it into bytecode—a set of low-level instructions. The CPython virtual machine executes them sequentially, ensuring cross-platform compatibility. However, unlike Java, Python interprets bytecode dynamically, providing the flexibility to change variable types at runtime. This allows you to write concise code that can be easily scaled for any business task.
python.full-sec-2-title: 2. Memory Management and the GIL Problem
python.full-sec-2-text: In Python, the primary memory cleanup mechanism is Reference Counting: an object is deleted as soon as no more references point to it. For cyclic references, a Garbage Collector is used. A crucial limitation is the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL). This mutex protects data thread-safety but restricts parallel execution of bytecode across different threads. To circumvent this in heavy tasks, we use the multiprocessing module or asynchrony.
python.full-sec-project-case-text: As I already mentioned in the main section of my portfolio, Python is my key tool. In this project, I used it to build the bot's modular architecture. To guarantee data purity, I applied the **Pydantic** library for strict validation of incoming objects. All the giveaway business logic was moved into separate asynchronous services, which made it possible to isolate the Telegram API from heavy computations. Also, for in-depth system state monitoring, the **Loguru** library was implemented, providing detailed logging of every automation step.

aiogram.tech-main-desc: Aiogram is a fully asynchronous framework built on top of asyncio. It encourages developers to write clean, typed, and modular code using modern web development patterns.
aiogram.tech-card-1-text: A multi-level system of filters and routers for managing data flows.
aiogram.tech-card-2-text: Implementation of user paths by persisting states in Redis or RAM.
aiogram.tech-card-3-text: Intermediate processing layers for implementing cross-cutting logic (logging, anti-spam).
aiogram.full-sec-1-text: In Aiogram, each event (Update) passes through a chain of Middlewares. This allows you to inject logic before the message reaches the main handler. For example, you can automatically check if a user is subscribed to a channel or limit request frequency (Rate limiting). This makes the system protected against abuse and allows you to move common logic into separate layers, without cluttering the command processing code.
aiogram.full-sec-2-text: To create complex interfaces, a Finite State Machine is used. It remembers which stage of the dialogue the user is at. To prevent data loss during a bot restart, we connect external storages (Redis/Postgres). This is the standard for Enterprise solutions, allowing you to seamlessly update the bot code without interrupting active user sessions.
aiogram.full-sec-project-case-text: As I already mentioned on the main page of my portfolio, I specialize in developing Telegram systems. In this project, I used **Aiogram 3.x** to build an asynchronous interaction architecture. I implemented a **Custom Middlewares** system to automatically check user subscription to sponsor channels before allowing entry to the giveaway. A state machine (**FSM**) with a **Redis** storage was also implemented, allowing administrators to configure giveaways step-by-step (uploading media, selecting a date, setting conditions) without losing progress even during a server reboot. To protect against cheating, I integrated custom filters on the dispatcher side that cut off suspicious bot activity.

postgres.tech-main-desc: PostgreSQL is an object-relational DBMS known for its reliability, support for complex queries, and strict adherence to ACID standards.
postgres.tech-card-1-text: Multi-Version Concurrency Control allows reading data without locks during writes.
postgres.tech-card-2-text: Guarantee of data integrity even during sudden power or system failures.
postgres.tech-card-3-text: Efficient handling of unstructured data within SQL tables.
postgres.full-sec-1-text: Postgres guarantees that each operation will either be fully completed or not at all (atomicity). The Write-Ahead Logging (WAL) mechanism records all changes to a log before they are applied to the table. This is critically important for financial or gaming systems where an error in a single record could lead to a loss of consistency across the entire database.
postgres.full-sec-2-text: We use not only standard B-tree indexes but also GIN indexes to speed up searches in JSONB fields. This allows Postgres to combine the speed of NoSQL solutions with the reliability of classical relational databases. Proper query planning (Explain Analyze) helps optimize load and ensure instant response even on million-row selections.
postgres.full-sec-project-case-text: As I already mentioned on the main page, I use databases to ensure maximum system stability. In this project, I chose PostgreSQL for its extensibility and reliability. To integrate with the bot's asynchronous code, I used **SQLAlchemy** together with the **asyncpg** driver, which allowed the database to work without blocking the main thread. I designed the relational schema so that even with 100,000+ participants, winner selection happens instantly. This was achieved by setting up composite **B-tree indexes** on user ID and giveaway ID fields, guaranteeing 100% data consistency during mass operations.

flask.tech-main-desc: Micro-frameworks for creating server-side logic and APIs. Flask is used for flexible admin panels, and FastAPI for high-performance asynchronous services with automatic data validation.
flask.tech-card-1-text: Architecture without boilerplate—connect only the modules you need for each task.
flask.tech-card-2-text: In FastAPI, data is automatically validated at the type level, eliminating request errors.
flask.tech-card-3-text: Automatic interactive API documentation is available 'out of the box'.
flask.full-sec-1-text: When designing the backend, I adhere to REST principles. Each resource corresponds to its own URL, and actions are defined by standard HTTP methods. FastAPI implements a powerful dependency injection (DI) system. This makes it easy to manage database connections, authentication, and settings, making the code modular and suitable for automatic testing. All data exchange occurs in JSON format, ensuring ideal compatibility with any frontend frameworks.
flask.full-sec-2-text: For Flask, we use Jinja2—a secure templating engine. It allows for dynamic HTML generation on the server by inserting data from Python directly into the markup. In the case of FastAPI, fully asynchronous I/O is used. This means the server doesn't 'sleep' during a long database request but continues processing other incoming calls. This is critically important for monitoring dashboards where data must be updated instantly.

git.tech-main-desc: Git is a distributed version control system that is the industry standard. It allows you to save a history of changes, work in a team, and safely experiment with code.
git.tech-card-1-text: Creating isolated branches for each new feature (Feature-driven development).
git.tech-card-2-text: Git stores complete snapshots of the project state, not file differences, for reliability.
git.tech-card-3-text: The ability to break changes into logical parts for easy rollback and analysis.
git.full-sec-1-text: Git is essentially a graph database. Each commit has a unique SHA-1 hash, which guarantees that the code content hasn't been altered unnoticed. Unlike older systems (SVN), Git stores complete file snapshots. This makes operations like switching between branches (checkout) and merging instant. Understanding concepts like the 'index' (staging area) and 'tree' allows me to efficiently manage even the most complex merge conflicts.
git.full-sec-2-text: For stable development, I use Git Flow. The main branch always contains only tested, production-ready code. Development occurs in the 'develop' branch, and each new feature is created in a separate 'feature/' branch. This prevents unfinished code from breaking the working system. Using commands like cherry-pick and rebase allows me to maintain a clean and understandable commit history, which is critical for long-term project maintenance.

frontend.tech-page-title: HTML / CSS / JS: The Visual Interface
frontend.tech-main-desc: The trio of technologies that shape the user experience. We use modern markup, styling, and scripting standards to create fast and responsive web applications.
frontend.tech-card-1-text: Layout using Flexbox and Grid for perfect display on all device types.
frontend.tech-card-2-text: Using asynchrony and modules in JS for smooth interface operation.
frontend.tech-card-3-text: Focus on intuitiveness, accessibility, and modern visual effects (Glassmorphism).
frontend.full-sec-1-text: Modern frontend is not just static pages. With JavaScript, I manipulate the DOM (Document Object Model) tree, dynamically changing the interface in response to user actions. Using the Fetch API allows for background data exchange with the backend. This creates the effect of a Single Page Application (SPA), where the page does not fully reload but only smoothly updates the necessary data blocks, significantly enhancing user comfort.
frontend.full-sec-2-text: For styling, I use CSS variables and modern positioning methods. This makes it easy to implement dark and light themes. Animations are implemented using hardware acceleration (transform: translate3d), guaranteeing smooth 60 FPS even on mobile devices. Special attention is paid to the layout methodology: I separate styles into logical modules so they can be easily reused in different parts of the project.
frontend.full-sec-project-case-text: As I already mentioned on the main page of my portfolio, I pay great attention not only to the code but also to the user's visual comfort. In this project, I implemented a responsive admin panel in pure **JavaScript** without using heavy frameworks, which ensured instant loading. I applied modern layout techniques (Flexbox and CSS Grid) to create a complex 'glass' interface (Glassmorphism) that remains readable on any device. All communication with the backend occurs through asynchronous **Fetch API** requests, allowing the administrator to manage giveaways and track participant statistics without a single page reload.

asyncio.tech-main-desc: Asyncio is a library to write concurrent code using the async/await syntax. It is the foundation for modern high-load systems handling thousands of network connections simultaneously.
asyncio.tech-card-1-text: The core loop that manages the execution of all tasks in a single thread.
asyncio.tech-card-2-text: Functions that can pause their work without blocking the entire program.
asyncio.tech-card-3-text: The system doesn't wait for network responses, switching to other tasks instantly.
asyncio.full-sec-1-text: Unlike classic threads, Asyncio uses a model where coroutines yield control back to the Event Loop. This eliminates race conditions for shared data and allows a single process to serve a colossal number of requests, consuming ten times less RAM. This makes Python ideal for microservices and bots.
asyncio.full-sec-2-text: Asyncio operates on low-level system calls (epoll/kqueue), allowing it to monitor thousands of sockets. The program 'sleeps' at the OS kernel level until data arrives. This ensures that one request's latency doesn't affect the overall throughput of the entire system.
asyncio.full-sec-project-case-text: **I didn't mention Asyncio on the main page**, but in this project, it was a key technology. I used asynchrony to implement **multi-accounting** — the bot can work with different Telegram sessions simultaneously without interference. Using `asyncio.gather()`, I configured parallel subscription checks in 5-10 channels at once. This reduced the user's waiting time from several seconds to milliseconds. Asynchronous queues (Tasks) also ensured stable background mailings that don't slow down the main bot interface during active giveaways.
